data.title: Extract the colors defined by editor as vs code custom settings in themes
data.body:
Currently editor has feature contributions those define some colors which does not go well with different themes. Extract those colors as vs code custom settings (non standard) in TM themes. This will allow theme writers to provide an appropriate matching color for these features.
### Range highlight (Find, Go to line, Go to symbol)
- [x] rangeHighlight
### Find / Replace (Find, Search, Reference)
- [x] findMatchHighlight
- [x] currentFindMatchHighlight
- [x] findRangeHighlight
### Selection
- [x] inactiveSelection
- [x] selectionHighlight
### Words
- [x] wordHighlight
- [x] wordHighlightStrong
### Link
- [x] activeLinkForeground
### Hover
- [x] hoverHighlight
### References
- [x] referenceHighlight

[Editor Decorations](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Editor-decorations-&-colors)

data.title: request for new system variable of ${worskpaceRootFolderName}
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

currently there is the system variable ${workspaceRoot}. This returns the full path to the workspace root so if your open folder is:

c:\folder1\folder2 then that is what ${workspaceRoot} returns.

that is fine if you want the full path returned but if you are developing a website and want to use tasks to intiate running the open file in a browser on local webserver, then you don't want the full path returned. You want the website root foldername returned so in above example you want just the foldername returned which would be "folder2". This has the benefit of greatly simplifying building a url to run in browser without resorting to coding.
For example you could build a url as 

${workspaceRootFolderName}/${relativeFile}

and pass that to your web browser with a task or key definition.

currently you would need to strip the foldername from ${workspaceRoot} and you can't do that in tasks.json file.

So please, please could we have an additional system variable with just the workspaceRoot folder name in it ( NOT the full path to it.)

I'm suggesting calling it ${workspaceRootFolderName}

(unless there is already some system variable I don't know about which could be used without needing to edit it).

Thanks

data.title: Changes cursor animations to start in default state.
data.body: Fixes #10922

data.title: Fixes debugger config launch for Linux and OSX.
Test: debug target launching in integrated terminal
data.body:
Test for #10574:
complexity: 4
- [x] Windows - **@ramya-rao-a**
- [x] OS X - **@sandy081**
- [x] Linux - **@rebornix**

In this milestone it is now possible to launch the node debug target in the 'integrated terminal' which helps when developing node.js-based command line applications that read from input and/or need to control the terminal they are running in.

Since there are now three options where to run a node program (debug console, integrated terminal, external terminal), we've deprecated the launch.json boolean attribute `externalConsole` and introduced a new attribute `console` which accepts the following values: `internalConsole`, `integratedTerminal`, `externalTerminal`.

Please verify:
- launching the debug target in the integrated terminal works. Make sure that passing arguments, environment variables, and 'cwd' work even if the values include spaces or quotes.
- the other two `console` options `internalConsole` and `externalConsole` continue to work.
- the new attribute `console` shows up in hover help and  newly created launch.json uses it instead of the deprecated `externalConsole`.
- the old `externalConsole` options still works if no `console` option is specified.

Please note:
The problem that every debug session creates a new terminal is already tracked here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10940

data.title: Please display the current absolute character cursor position (in the entire document)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Sometimes instead of getting errors relative to the lines (i.e. line 5, position 14),  you get errors relative to the absolute position of the character in the entire file. Errors messages like this:

```
ParsingException: Unexpected character encountered while parsing value at position 116
```

It would be useful to be able to know what the 116th character of the entire file is. Currently there is no way to know that in Visual Studio Code.

The only information displayed in the bottom bar is the Row and Column. So I can know the character at a certain position in a line, but I don't know what is the absolute character number (including hidden formatting characters like new line, eof, etc).

It would be awesome to be able to see instead of this:

> row 1, col 5

This:

> row 1, col 5, chr 116

It should also be useful to be able to programmatically move the cursor to a new position using the absolute position of the character instead of the line, column coordinates. So that instead of being able to do just this:

> var newPosition = position.with(position.line, 5);

You would be also able to do this:

> var newPosition = position.with(116);

In this way when a compiler log will give you an absolute character number position for an error in you file, your code extension can immediately position the cursor in that exact place, hilighting the right character that rised the exception.

data.title: Test: reopen closed tabs opens at previous index
data.body:
- [x] any OS @gregvanl

We landed https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9459 and need to verify that:
- you can reopen closed tabs via `File | Open Recent | Reopen Closed Editor` as before
- editors that reopen will be opened at the index they previously closed, thus maintaining the ordering of editors if possible

data.title: Support embedded modes for TextMate grammars
data.body:
With TextMate grammars we no longer support embedded modes which control the behaviour of smart editing (brackets, comments).

Text mate scopes can be used for that, but we should fix the flattening of scopes first (#3008)

data.title: False positive of hangs and ESC key reboot vscode unexpectedly.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  - 1.5.0-insider
  - 31f1acb8c82b8a19256d5d56127d3f81edce3745
  - 2016-08-26T08:00:03.472Z
  - Shell: 0.37.6
  - Renderer: 49.0.2623.75
  - Node: 5.10.0
- OS Version:
  - Windows 7 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Show context menu in file explorer of vscode.
2. Keep showing 30s. Then VSCode shows hang up dialog unexpectedly.
   ![false-positive](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1937871/18042217/8ad7d8ec-6dfa-11e6-86d6-f9709ad04bb8.gif)
3. Press **ESC key**. I expected that I can continue my work, but VSCode does rebooting. I had lost my works... I think ESC key should do nothing.

data.title: Quick open: out of workspace results no longer showing up
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. open a folder as workspace
2. open some files that are outside of that folder via File > open
3. clear editor history (from F1 list)
4. start to search in quick open for the out of workspace files

=> no results show up

This seems to be caused by the cached query not setting any `extraFileResources`

@chrmarti please review my attempt to fix this in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/83b97d009f5eb2493ca88983c9b5ed4742ba0dc1

data.title: Navigating back after a 'go to declaration' might leave the cursor in a slightly different spot
data.body:
Say you have this code -

```
function f() {



}

setInterval(f, 1000);
```
1. Click in the middle of `setInterval`, then next to `f`
2. Press F12 to go to the declaration
3. Press ctrl+- to navigate back
4. The cursor will be in the middle of `setInterval`, not where it was when pressing F12.

Looks like we don't save cursor position changes unless they are somewhat far from the previous position, so when navigating back, we end up somewhere near where we came from, but not the exact spot. Maybe when doing a navigation like for pressing F12, we should save the original position of the cursor in the history stack?

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.4 (latest stable) - OS Version: MacOS The title for the git comparison editor can be very long and doesn't leave a lot of room for displaying other tab titles: Perhaps the tab text can be shortened a bit? Instead of `foo.txt ↔ foo.text (HEAD)`, perhaps something like `↔ foo.txt (HEAD)`? For long file names, this could cut the length of the tab title nearly in half.

data.title: Console corrupts non-latin output encoding
data.body:
Tests, programm output, etc.

```
[<Theory>]
    [<InlineData("キ", "Ки")>]
    let ``Should transcribes words from Japanese to Russian with D-form normalization``(input, output) = 
        let container = Utils.getContainer dicPath
        let ming = new Floxdc.Ming.Control.Ming(container)

        let result = ming.Transcribe(input, "d")

        Assert.Equal(output, input)
```

```
Tests.Integration.Japanese.Should transcribes words from Japanese to Russian with D-form normalization(input: "?", output: "��") [FAIL]
      Assert.Equal() Failure
                 (pos 0)
      Expected: ��
      Actual:   ?
                 (pos 0)
```
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (31f1acb8c82b8a19256d5d56127d3f81edce3745, 2016-08-26T08:00:03.472Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
